716626f-a.text:
27 Beaver Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Broad Street. The building was awarded second prize by the Downtown League for
the best alteration in the year.
1924.
Albert Rothschild.
716626f-a.folder: Beaver Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

716908f-c.text:
(1)
76-108 Broad Street, from south of Marketfield Street to Water Street. On the right, with the flagpole, is the Maritime Exchange. The small building in the centre houses the Bush Terminal Company, and behind it looms the 17-story New York Telephone Company Building.
1924.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, six years later.
April 27, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
76-122 Broad Street, west side, from south of Marketfield Street
to Front Street.
April 27, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

716906f-a.text:
The Consolidated Stock Exchange Building in the last stage of demolition, 69-65 Broad Street, at the S.E. corner of Beaver Street. The proposed Lefcourt Exchange Building announced by the sign, will fail to materialize, and the 35-story International Telephone and Telegraph Building will occupy this site and later cover the entire block from Beaver to South William Streets.

About 1926.

Neg. # 370
716906f-a.folder: Broad Street & Beaver Street, Manhattan, NY

716905f-a.text:
68-76 Broad Street, west side, from Beaver to south of Marketfield Streets, seen across the excavation for the International Telephone and Telegraph Building, also showing 30-20 Beaver Street, south side, from Broad Street to east of New Street. The building in right centre is the American Bank
Note Company.
August 29, 1927.
P.L. Sperr.
716905f-a.folder: Broad Street & Beaver Street, Manhattan, NY

716627f-a.text:
Beaver Street, south side, west from, but not including Broad, to and including Broadway. Shown at the S.E. corner of Broadway, is the N.Y. Pro
duce Exchange Buildin2.
October 13, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
716627f-a.folder: Beaver Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

716907f-a.text:
70-30 Broad Street, west side, from and including Beaver Street to,but not quite including Exchange Place. The American Banknote Company Building is seen in the left foreground. The Johnston Building, in the right background, will be torn down in 1931 and the 48-story Continental Bank Trust Company Building
erected on its site.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway.
